meta_description: ICA at VCU presents the art of our time and provides an open forum for dialogue and collaboration across the region and throughout the world.
hours_text:
## _BUILDING HOURS_

The ICA’s normal hours are Tuesday-Sunday 10 AM-5 PM.

#### COST

* * *

Admission to the ICA is always free. Certain programs may require advance registration.

#### PARKING

* * *

We are located at the intersection of Belvidere and Broad streets in the center of Richmond.  
[601 W. Broad Street.,Richmond, VA 23220](http://web.archive.org/web/20250909095835/https://www.google.com/maps/dir//VCU+Institute+for+Contemporary+Art,+818+W+Broad+St,+Richmond,+VA+23220/@37.5485899,-77.4475506,15z/data=!4m15!1m6!3m5!1s0x0:0x46360c09ed17f505!2sVCU+Institute+for+Contemporary+Art!8m2!3d37.55003!4d-77.4489395!4m7!1m0!1m5!1m1!1s0x89b11148767677e9:0x46360c09ed17f505!2m2!1d-77.4489395!2d37.55003)

Metered parking by the hour (4 hour limit) is available in the VCU QQ Lot located at 612 W. Grace Street, directly adjacent to the ICA.

Paid VCU parking decks are nearby at 1111 W. Broad Street and 801 W. Main Street.  
Parking can also be found on adjacent streets. Please observe all posted signs and parking regulations.

_We encourage you to bike, walk, or use public transit.[Plan your trip](http://web.archive.org/web/20250909095835/http://ridegrtc.com/planning-your-trip/trip-planner/) using Richmond Public Transit (GRTC)._

#### ACCESSIBILITY

* * *

We’ve designed our space and our programs to be accessible to all. The ICA is accessible to those using wheelchairs or other mobility devices. All galleries and the auditorium are accessible by elevator.

As a part of VCU, we’r...

About this capture

COLLECTED BY

Organization: [Archive Team](https://archive.org/details/archiveteam)

Formed in 2009, the Archive Team (not to be confused with the archive.org Archive-It Team) is a rogue archivist collective dedicated to saving copies of rapidly dying or deleted websites for the sake of history and digital heritage. The group is 100% composed of volunteers and interested parties, and has expanded into a large amount of related projects for saving online and digital history. 

History is littered with hundreds of conflicts over the future of a community, group, location or business that were "resolved" when one of the parties stepped ahead and destroyed what was there. With the original point of contention destroyed, the debates would fall to the wayside. Archive Team believes that by duplicated condemned data, the conversation and debate can continue, as well as the richness and insight gained by keeping the materials.
